column2: Regency,,,,,,,"This is a dark red silk velvet waistcoat. It is trimmed with silver braid and lined with cerise silk. It forms part of the costume worn by Sake Deen Mahomed. This item was donated to Brighton Museum & Art Gallery in 1949.

column1: Brighton's most famous baths were built by Sake Deen Mahomed, who was born in India and moved to Brighton in 1786. He set up the first 'Turkish' baths in the country and offered indoor bathing, steam rooms and massage, then known as shampooing, as medical cures. After writing publications on the success of his cures, he became 'Shampooing Surgeon' to King George IV and William IV. Sake Deen died in 1851 aged 102.",dmas_ct003587_d01_cc1024.jpg,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,

CT003813,Costume,Coat,,Shirin Guild,2000,,,,,Wool,,"This is a red wool abba coat made in London in 2000 by Shirin Guild.

This coat is based on the traditional Iranian abba coat, which is a large square cut cloak, worn to protect from the dust and weather in the Middle East. In Arabia, Syria, and some areas of Iran, wealthy Arabs wear silk versions of the abba coat, woven with gold or silver patterns in gilt thread.

Shirin Guild launched her own label in London in 1991. Her outfits, which are loose fitting and simple, are inspired by the men_s wear from her native Iran.  Using yarns made from paper, hemp, bamboo and steel covered with silk, Shirin Guild reworks traditional male Iranian dress for the modern day woman. In this case she has taken the abba coat and recreated it in a striking vivid red.",dmas_ct003813_d01_cc1024.jpg

CT003891,Costume,Jacket,,Unrecorded,1967-c1968,,,,Hippy,Brocade textile,,"This is a yellow jacket made around 1968, worn by a Hippy.

This Oriental style jacket has a high mandarin collar and an embroidered Chinese pattern of flowers in light yellow, pink, blue and green. Many Hippy clothes and styles were influenced by other cultures, partly due to the amount of Hippies that travelled in the 1960_s (most famously on the _Hippy trail_) but also because Hippy_s believed in a inclusive world which valued and respected all cultures. As a result Hippies often incorporated clothes and accessories from other cultures into their look.
This jacket was donated to Brighton Museum in 2001. The jacket is part of the Renegade collection illustrating the history of sub cultures in Brighton.",dmas_ct003891_d01_cc1024.jpg
CT003894,Costume,Bag,,Lulu Guinness,2001,,,,,Satin,,"This is a Lulu Guinness bag made in London in 2001.

This satin bag has been made to look as if it is a small black wicker basket filled with pink flowers. The lid of the basket, which has the fabric flowers attached to it, lifts up so items can be placed inside

column1: Lulu Guinness is a self-taught designer who started her own label in 1989. She revolutionised women_s handbags when she launched her sculpted bags in the 1990_s.  The bags, which came in all shapes and sizes (from a London bus to a woman_s corset), had never been seen before but they were an instant hit. Widely copied they are now a common sight on our high streets.",dmas_ct003894_d01_cc1024.jpg
CT003895,Costume,Jacket,,Unrecorded,c1977,,,,Punk,Leather
column2: Metal,,"This is a black leather jacket made c1977, worn by a Punk. The jacket has been customised with the slogan _Highly Fucking Offensive_ painted on one arm in white and a patch added to the other arm reading _Triumph_. On the back is a painted scene in black and white of soldiers, an atomic cloud, a swastika, a crucifix, the red stripes of a union jack and the date _1984_ (this is a reference to the novel by George Orwell) all surrounding the words _Killing Joke_. The jacket is an example of the Punk style, which was dark and aggressive, in direct opposition to the Hippy subculture that had gone before. Clothes - like this jacket - were hand painted with angry slogans and symbols such as the swastika, designed to shock.

column1: The jacket was donated to Brighton Museum in 2001and is part of the Renegade collection, which illustrates the history of subcultures in Brighton.",dmas_ct003895_d03_cc1024.jpg

column2: Silk,,"This evening coat was worn by Maud Messel. It is made of dark red and gilt tissue brocade, figured with large clusters of art deco, oriental-inspired floral motifs.  The Chinoiserie (Western interpretations of Chinese styles) was especially evident in the patterning of fashionable 1920s textiles.  Exotic floral, latticework and dragon motifs were all popular. column2: Fur,,"This evening coat was worn by Maud Messel. It is made of dark blue silk, with a modified oriental design embroidered in cream. The coat is full-length, wraps over at the front and fastens on the left with two large fabric buttons.  It has a high stand-up collar made of soft fur. The style of this coat was highly fashionable in the early 1920s and reveals Maud Messel to be an elegant and stylish dresser aged 48.  The coat is designed by Reville of London and dates from circa 1923. Reville opened as a court dressmaker in 1905, at that time it was called Reville & Rossiter. In 1910 the company was appointed court dressmakers to Queen Mary. During the early 1920s it was one the most fashionable London couturiers.

CT004114,Costume,Jacket,,Unrecorded,c1890-1910,,,,,Silk,,"This Chinese jacket was worn by Maud Messel. It is made of yellow silk brocade lined in red silk.  It is decorated around the neck, hem and on the side seams with blue silk bordered with purple silk and a black embroidered band.  The blue silk is embroidered with scenes of Chinese people around a lake.  The jacket is calf length, it has wide sleeves with wide blue silk turned back cuffs, embroidered with large stylised fruit and flowers.  It is collarless and fastens at the side.    It is likely that this jacket was a present from Maud_s uncle Edgar Herapath, who traveled in China.  Jackets were popular tourist souvenirs as they were easily transportable. It was made in China to be worn by a Han woman, in circa 1890-1910.  It is unlikely that Maud wore this jacket as only the most avant garde women in this period wore Chinese dress.  But it would have appealed to her romantic interest in the _Orient_.
This jacket is part of the Messel Dress Collection, which includes six generations of one family_s clothes dating from 1870 - 2005.",dmas_ct004114_d01_cc1024.jpg

column2: Glass,,"This ball dress was worn by Maud Messel. It is made of purple velveteen.  It is full length with a large train trimmed with frills of purple silk. The boned bodice has a turned back collar revealing inner layers of cream net and cream guipure lace with purple drawstrings. The high waist is decorated front and back with metal edged velveteen bows set with purple gems. A long cream guipure lace 'scarf' is attached at the centre back of the waist, this drapes over the shoulders, hangs down the front of the skirt, and is secured at the right side of the waist with a bow. The scarf is trimmed at the ends with pink tassels. The dress has elbow length open sleeves trimmed with beaded tassels and long net under sleeves.  The designer of the dress is unknown and it dates from circa 1907 -1908.  It is an example of Maud Messel's fashionable evening wear of this period.

CT004377,Costume,Evening Dress,,Irene Gilbert,c1960,,,,,Silk,,"This evening dress was worn by Anne, Countess of Rosse in 1960. It is made of cream silk, embroidered with large deep pink carnations with black stems. The dress has a fitted bodice, decorated with an embroidered carnation appliqu‚d below the halter neckline. column2: Silk,,This is a pair of dark pink leather shoes made in Turkey in the mid nineteenth century. column1: CT004999,Costume,Trousers,,Maharishi,1999,,,,,Cotton,,"This is a pair of grey cotton Maharishi trousers made in 1999.

These trousers are loose fitting with a drawstring waist, tucks at the knee and drawstring around the hem. On the back of the right leg is a large embroidered dragon in pink, black and camouflage designed by graffiti artist Steven Tsang. On the back of the right leg is a smaller embroidered rabbit (also in camouflage) with the numbers 63, 75, 87 and 99. The trousers were made in the Chinese Year of the Rabbit (1999) hence the embroidered rabbit, the other figures refer to the last four years of the rabbit.

These trousers with their modern style and shape (they look like lightweight combat trousers), design by a graffiti artist and references to Chinese culture make these a typical Maharishi piece. column4: Silk,,"This is a complete outfit: coat, jacket, breeches, belt, stockings and shoes, made in 1821 worn by a canopy bearer at the coronation of George IV.

column1: The bodice, which is worn over the coat, is made from red satin with a high collar edged in gold braid with short puffed sleeves with a slash effect, which reveals the blue material underneath. The knee length coat also has a high collar but is made from blue satin with a red satin lining, hand-stitched with long detachable sleeves (also with the slash effect). The coat is fitted into and flaring out from the waist. The knee length breeches are made from red satin also slashed to reveal a layer of blue satin. They are decorated with gold braid around the bottom of the leg, fastening with blue satin buttons. Worn over the top is a black velvet belt that would hold the canopy bearer_s sword. Red silk stockings keep the legs warm while a pair of white leather shoes (partly lined in red silk) with a flat red leather heel decorated with a large gold and red rosette finish the outfit.
The makers mark inside reads 10: Charing Cross: London: Country dealers supplied on low terms.

This outfit was worn by Thomas Davies Lamb: Baron of the _Cinque Ports_. The Cinque Ports were towns that mended and looked after the Crown_s ships - making sure they were ready for action if there was any trouble. The barons held powerful positions because they were in charge of the ports. One of the baron_s duties for the Crown was to be a canopy bearer: the person who carried a canopy over a monarch in their coronation. The canopy used for George IV_s coronation was heavy and difficult to carry. George walked in front of it as he was worried it would fall on his head, a canopy has not been used in a coronation procession since!",dmas_ctmas000043_d01_cc1024.jpg

CTMAS000048,Costume,Pyjamas,,Unrecorded,c1920,,,,,Silk satin,,"This is a blue satin pyjama outfit: vest, jacket and trousers made in circa 1920.

The sleeveless vest is edged in white piping. It has two heart shaped patch pockets and is embroidered around the neckline with two white silk Chinese dragons. There are belt loops on either side of the vest. The belt is missing.

The jacket is also edged in white piping and is embroidered near each cuff with a white Chinese sun. It has a Chinese dragon embroidered in white silk on each front corner. On the back is embroidered a large sun and a dragon. The jacket fastens with one button and a loop.

The trousers have an elasticated waist with a v shaped panel below just below the waistband. The legs are wide cut and flaring with four long light cream satin triangular inserts embroidered with Chinese dragons in purple silk. The hem is edged in blue satin and white satin piping.

During the 1920_s oriental styled clothing was fashionable. Chinese dragons and flowers were in keeping with the Art Deco movement of that time. The Chinese dragons on these pyjamas may be shen-lung, a controller of the weather.  Pyjamas became fashionable in the mid-1920s, replacing the tea gown as informal wear
column2: they were also one of the earliest acceptable forms of fashionable trousers for women. column1: This dress has a neckline trimmed with lace, short puffed sleeves and a full length skirt, with the front decorated with lace and white embroidery. The inder dress is made from white cotton with drawstring fastenings at the neck and waist.  Embroidered white muslin dresses such as this one were fashionable in the early 1800_s. Fine muslins, or mulls, were produced in Bengal, India and imported into Britain by the East India companies. By the end of the 18th century Britain_s textile industry had improved so that raw cotton (imported from India and America) was woven in the mills of northern England. This dress would have been worn with a coloured Indian (or imitation) shawl, contrasting with the plain white of the dress.",dmas_ctmas000052_d01_cc1024.jpg

CTMAS000111,Costume,Day Dress,,Unrecorded,c1885,,,,,Velvet and silk,,"This day dress was worn by Marion Sambourne once her period of mourning for her father who died in 1884 had finished. The dress is made up of a dark green silk velvet bodice and a green silk skirt brocaded with large spots. The cuirasse bodice is cut in panels from shoulder to hip, with a prominent bustle and a wide train at the back. It has spotted green silk facings and trims and a high standing collar.  The full-length sleeves have a double frill at the cuffs.  The skirt is pleated at the front from hip to hem, with a green silk velvet border beneath.  This sombre but fashionably styled outfit would have been worn for formal afternoon occasions.  The designer of the dress is unknown.  It dates from circa 1885.
This dress is part of the Messel Dress Collection, which includes six generations of one family_s clothes dating from 1870 - 2005.",dmas_ctmas000111_d01_cc1024.jpg
